cluster_classes.class_description: Steels that are prone to graphitization, a microstructural change causing loss of strength and ductility.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Graphitization affects carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels.

members.entity_description: Steels that do not have alloying elements intentionally added, but may contain small amounts of elements and are affected by graphitization under certain conditions.
A type of steel that undergoes graphitization at elevated temperatures.
A type of steel susceptible to graphitization, especially with up to 1% Mo.
Steels with up to 9% chromium and other alloys for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

cluster_classes.class_description: Steels engineered for use in high-temperature environments, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types, valued for strength and creep resistance.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Used for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

members.entity_description: A type of steel used for thick wall reactor vessels in petroleum refinery processes.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes involving the transformation of carbide phases into graphite nodules in steels at elevated temperatures.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Transformation of carbide phases into graphite nodules.

members.entity_description: Change in microstructure of carbon and 0.5Mo steels causing loss of strength and ductility.
Result of carbide phase decomposition in steels at elevated temperatures, forming graphite nodules.

cluster_classes.class_description: The Heat Affected Zone (HAZ) is the area of base metal near a weld that has not melted but has undergone changes in microstructure and mechanical properties due to welding heat.

members.entity_description: The portion of the base metal adjacent to a weld with altered microstructure and properties due to welding heat.

args.new_description: Steels prone to graphitization, including carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels, which lose strength and ductility due to microstructural changes.
args.new_class_group: Steel Graphitization and High-Temperature Steel Phenomena
args.justification: Class_Group 'Steel Graphitization' is too narrow; entities and evidence show overlap with high-temperature steel performance and damage mechanisms, so a broader Class_Group is needed.

args.new_description: Steels engineered for high-temperature environments, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types, valued for strength and creep resistance and relevant to graphitization phenomena.
args.new_class_group: Steel Graphitization and High-Temperature Steel Phenomena
args.justification: Class_Group should be broadened to connect high-temperature steels with graphitization-susceptible steels, as both are semantically and technically linked in the evidence.

args.new_description: Processes involving the transformation of carbide phases into graphite nodules in steels at elevated temperatures, leading to loss of strength and ductility.
args.new_class_group: Steel Graphitization and High-Temperature Steel Phenomena
args.justification: Class_Group should be broadened to encompass both material and transformation phenomena relevant to high-temperature steel performance and graphitization.

args.new_description: The area of base metal near a weld that has not melted but has undergone changes in microstructure and mechanical properties due to welding heat.
args.justification: This class is unrelated to the steel graphitization and high-temperature steel phenomena cluster and should remain in its current, distinct Class_Group.
